citation.article-title: Recharacterization and emended description of the genus Mycoplana and description of two new species Mycoplana ramosa and Mycoplana segnis.

p.s: Description of Mycoplana ramosa sp. nov.
Mycoplana ramosa (ra.mo'sa. M.L. ramosa, ramous, ramose, branched, branchlike)
Positive for reduction of nitrate, the Voges-Proskauer test, and catalase activity.

Acid is produced from L-arabinose, D-xylose, D-glucose, D-mannose, D-fructose, D-galactose, D-sorbitol, D-mannitol, and glycerol oxidatively, but is not produced from maltose, sucrose, lactose, trehalose, inositol, and soluble starch.

L-Arabinose, D-xylose, D-glucose, D-mannose, D-fructose, D-galactose, D-sorbitol, D-mannitol, glycerol, L-glutamic acid, L-asparatic acid, acetic acid, putrescine, spermidine, and spermine are utilized as sole sources of carbon, but maltose, sucrose, lactose, trehalose, inositol, soluble starch, succinic acid, citric acid, formic acid, methanol, ethanol, n-butanol, monomethylamine, methane, and butane are not.
The DNA base composition is 64 mol% G+C.
The major hydroxy fatty acid is 3-hydroxy-C14:0 acid.
The type strain is strain TK0053 (= NCIB 9440), which is strain M51 of Macdonald College and was isolated from soil by Gray and Thornton in 1928.
This strain was deposited previously in the NCIB as an M. bullata strain.
